strategic_profile.executive_summary: New York University (NYU) is a highly selective private research university located in New York City, renowned for its global presence with degree-granting campuses worldwide and a strong emphasis on diverse academic and research opportunities. Its urban campus is deeply integrated into the vibrant life of New York, offering students an immersive city experience alongside rigorous academics.
strategic_profile.admissions_philosophy: NYU employs a test-optional policy through the 2025-2026 application cycle, offering applicants flexibility in submitting standardized test scores. While not explicitly stated as 'holistic' in all search results, the highly selective nature, low acceptance rate (7.7% for the Class of 2029), and requirement for essays and letters of recommendation suggest a comprehensive, individualized review of applicants.

analyst_takeaways.insight: NYU's acceptance rate has dropped significantly, reaching a record low of 7.7% for the Class of 2029.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Applicants should focus on presenting a strong and distinctive profile beyond just academic metrics to stand out in a highly competitive pool. Early application might be beneficial.

analyst_takeaways.insight: NYU remains test-optional through the 2025-2026 application cycle, offering a flexible testing policy.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Students have the choice to submit scores if they believe it strengthens their application, but it is not a requirement. This may attract a broader range of applicants.

analyst_takeaways.insight: NYU's campus is an integral part of New York City, with buildings scattered throughout Manhattan and Brooklyn.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Students seeking a traditional, self-contained campus experience might find NYU's urban integration challenging, while those desiring an immersive city life will thrive. Networking and internship opportunities are vast due to this integration.

campus_dynamics.social_environment: NYU's social environment is diverse and highly integrated with New York City life. Students engage in a wide array of activities, from numerous student clubs and organizations to exploring the city's cultural, entertainment, and dining scenes. Washington Square Park serves as a central gathering spot, and residence halls foster community, especially for first-year students. The social scene caters to both studious individuals and those seeking vibrant nightlife.
campus_dynamics.transportation_impact: Transportation is a significant aspect of campus life, as NYU's 'campus' is the city itself. The vast majority of the NYU community relies on mass transit (subway, bus) and walking for commuting. A university shuttle system also connects major academic locations, including its Manhattan and Brooklyn campuses. Navigating the city is an essential skill, and the public transportation system becomes an extension of the learning environment for many students, particularly commuters.
campus_dynamics.research_impact: As a prominent research university, NYU provides extensive research opportunities for both undergraduate and graduate students across its many schools and institutes. Research is broadly defined to include artistic and professional activities alongside traditional academic inquiry. Students can engage in one-on-one work with faculty, participate in specialized programs, and contribute to significant projects. NYU is a leader in research funding and innovation, boasting strong industry ties through various centers and initiatives.

longitudinal_trends.notes: Record number of applications. Acceptance rate hit an all-time low of 7.7%. Yield rate is 'TBA' for this class. Waitlist data is not publicly disclosed by NYU.

Acceptance rate of 9.2% is based on the 2024-2025 Common Data Set for Fall 2024 enrollment. Some sources also reported 8% acceptance rate for Class of 2028. Yield rate was reported as 55.4% or 60.4%. Waitlist data is not publicly disclosed by NYU.
Acceptance rate of 9.4%. Yield rate is 'TBA' for this class. Waitlist data is not publicly disclosed by NYU and the waitlist was unranked according to the 2022-2023 CDS.

100,662 applications were reported in the Common Data Set for 2021-2022. News releases at the time indicated over 105,000 applications. Acceptance rate was 12.2%. Enrolled total is approximate. Yield rate calculated based on approximate enrolled and admitted figures. Waitlist data is not publicly disclosed by NYU and the waitlist was unranked.

Over 100,000 applications were reported across all NYU campuses (New York, Abu Dhabi, and Shanghai). Acceptance rate for the New York campus was 12.8%. Enrolled total is approximate. Yield rate calculated based on approximate enrolled and admitted figures. Waitlist data is not publicly disclosed by NYU.

Acceptance rate of 15% for the New York campus. Yield rate calculated based on approximate enrolled and admitted figures. Some sources report acceptance rates as high as 21% or 29.8% for this class year, possibly reflecting different campus inclusions or calculation methodologies. Waitlist data is not publicly disclosed by NYU.

gpa.notes: Average weighted GPA is 3.81. The typical unweighted GPA for most first-years is 3.7 (A). Most admits would have mostly A's, ideally with several AP or IB classes.

testing.policy_note: Test optional but recommended. For enrolled students, 28% submitted SAT scores and 10% submitted ACT scores (Fall 2024 Common Data Set data).

colleges.name: College of Arts & Science
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Strong academic record and intellectual curiosity are essential. Emphasize ability to thrive in a broad liberal arts curriculum within an urban setting.
colleges.housing_profile: Vibrant urban living in diverse residence halls, community-oriented with social activities. First-year students may be part of the Residential College at the Paulson Center, offering integrated living and learning experiences including a dedicated writing course.
colleges.student_archetype: Intellectually curious, academically rigorous, independent thinkers, often with pre-professional interests (e.g., pre-med).

majors.name: Computer Science
majors.notes: Overall CAS acceptance rate is 4%. No specific prerequisites are generally required for CAS internal transfers, but strong performance in relevant courses is noted.

majors.name: Economics
majors.notes: Overall CAS acceptance rate is 4%. Strong performance in introductory economics and math courses is beneficial.

majors.name: Biology
majors.notes: Overall CAS acceptance rate is 4%. Foundational science courses often serve as early filters.

majors.name: Psychology
weeder_courses: STAT-UA 103 Statistics for the Behavioral Sciences
majors.notes: Overall CAS acceptance rate is 4%. Introductory courses are key.

majors.name: Neural Science
majors.notes: Overall CAS acceptance rate is 4%. Strong performance in foundational sciences is expected.

colleges.name: Leonard N. Stern School of Business
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Demonstrate strong analytical skills, leadership potential, and a clear interest in business. Highlight relevant experiences and achievements.
colleges.housing_profile: Vibrant urban living in diverse residence halls, community-oriented with social activities. First-year students may be part of the Residential College at the Paulson Center, fostering a sense of belonging amidst city life.
colleges.student_archetype: Highly ambitious, career-focused, entrepreneurial, and driven, often described as 'finance bros' in jest but serious about their professional goals.

majors.name: Business (General, with concentrations)
majors.notes: Extremely competitive for internal transfer, with an internal transfer acceptance rate of 2% in 2019. Recommended GPA of 3.8 or higher, with A- or better in prerequisites like Calculus, Financial Accounting, Microeconomics, and Statistics. Internal transfers can only apply for the Fall semester.

colleges.name: Tandon School of Engineering
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Strong background in STEM subjects (math, science, computer science) is crucial. Showcase problem-solving skills and innovative thinking.
colleges.housing_profile: Vibrant urban living in diverse residence halls, community-oriented with social activities. First-year students may be part of the Residential College at the Paulson Center, promoting connections within a 'small community' feel.
colleges.student_archetype: Ambitious problem-solvers, innovative, technically skilled, often focused on specific engineering or tech fields.

majors.name: Computer Science
majors.notes: A technical GPA of at least 2.0 in ECE and CS courses is generally required. Grades of at least C- are required in core CS courses.

majors.name: Mechanical Engineering
majors.notes: A GPA of at least 2.0 in all courses is required for the degree. Specific foundational courses in math, physics, and engineering are critical.

majors.name: Electrical Engineering
majors.notes: A technical GPA of at least 2.0 is required in all ECE and CS courses. A grade of at least C- is required in CS-UY 1114, ECE-UY 2204, ECE-UY 2004, and ECE-UY 3054.

majors.name: Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering
majors.notes: Degree requires 128 credits with at least a 2.0 GPA in all courses.

colleges.name: Tisch School of the Arts
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Exceptional artistic talent demonstrated through a strong portfolio, audition, or creative submissions. Passion for the arts and storytelling.
colleges.housing_profile: Vibrant urban living in diverse residence halls, fostering a close-knit university community. First-year students may be part of the Residential College at the Paulson Center, with opportunities for engagement and events.
colleges.student_archetype: Creative, artistic, expressive, individualistic, often seen as unconventional and dedicated to their craft.

majors.name: Film and Television
majors.notes: Highly competitive for internal transfers. Artistic review is a critical component of the application. Spring start internal transfer application deadline is April 1st.

majors.name: Drama
majors.notes: Highly competitive for internal transfers. Artistic review is a critical component of the application. Spring start internal transfer application deadline is April 1st.

majors.name: Performance Studies
majors.notes: Internal transfer is possible, and requires strong academic standing.

colleges.name: Gallatin School of Individualized Study
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Demonstrate strong intellectual curiosity, self-direction, and an ability to design an interdisciplinary course of study. Emphasize unique academic interests.
colleges.housing_profile: Vibrant urban living in diverse residence halls, encouraging community formation. First-year students may join the Residential College at the Paulson Center, designed to create a greater sense of connection and belonging.
colleges.student_archetype: Independent thinkers, highly self-motivated, interdisciplinary, comfortable forging their own academic path.

majors.name: Individualized Study (Concentration)
majors.special_requirements: Individualized Concentration Plan (Intellectual Autobiography and Plan for Concentration) approved by advisor. Colloquium (oral defense of concentration).
majors.notes: Students design their own interdisciplinary concentration. A minimum cumulative GPA of 2.0 is required for academic good standing. Maximum of 64 transfer units allowed. Students with 48+ units or rising juniors must complete a Concentration Planning Worksheet upon admission.

colleges.name: Rory Meyers College of Nursing
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Strong academic performance in science courses, demonstrated interest in healthcare, empathy, and commitment to service.
colleges.housing_profile: Vibrant urban living in diverse residence halls, offering a 'small community' feel within the city. First-year students may be part of the Residential College at the Paulson Center, featuring themed engagement and faculty interaction.
colleges.student_archetype: Compassionate, dedicated, scientifically-minded, focused on health and patient care.

majors.name: Nursing
majors.notes: Prerequisite courses must be completed with a C or better. A strong GPA (around 3.5 or higher) is recommended for transfer students. Students begin nursing coursework after completing liberal arts and science prerequisites.

colleges.name: Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Showcase passion for fields like education, nutrition, media, or performing arts. Emphasize relevant experiences and a desire to impact human development.
colleges.housing_profile: Vibrant urban living in diverse residence halls, fostering an inclusive and engaging social environment. The Residential College at the Paulson Center is available for first-year students.
colleges.student_archetype: Socially conscious, creative, often interested in public service, education, or arts integration, with a global mindset.

majors.name: Applied Psychology
prerequisite_courses: APSY-UE 2 Introduction to Psychology and Its Principles
weeder_courses: APSY-UE 2 Introduction to Psychology and Its Principles
majors.notes: To transfer for sophomore year, APSY-UE 2 with B- or better is required. For junior year, APSY-UE 2 and APSY-UE 10 with B- or better are required. Recommended 2.7 GPA or better to make satisfactory academic progress.

majors.name: Media, Culture, and Communication
majors.notes: MCC only accepts transfers for the Fall semester. Students must complete MCC-UE 0001 and MCC-UE 003 with a B- or better in each course *before applying*. A B (3.0) cumulative GPA is recommended. Receiving below a B- in two or more MCC core courses may require exploring other major options.

colleges.name: Liberal Studies
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Ideal for students seeking a strong liberal arts foundation with expansive global programs, often leading to transition into other NYU schools. Emphasize broad academic interests.
colleges.housing_profile: Vibrant urban living in diverse residence halls, promoting a close-knit university community. First-year students may reside in the Residential College at the Paulson Center, offering unique opportunities for engagement.
colleges.student_archetype: Globally minded, adaptable, foundational learners, seeking a broad education before specializing.

colleges.name: School of Professional Studies
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Focus on career-oriented interests and practical skills in various professional fields. Often attracts non-traditional or working students.
colleges.housing_profile: Vibrant urban living in diverse residence halls, designed to create a sense of belonging amidst the high energy of NYC. Residential College is primarily for first-year undergraduates.
colleges.student_archetype: Pragmatic, career-focused, often looking for direct application of knowledge to professional industries.

minors_certificates: Business of Entertainment, Media and Technology Minor

supplemental_requirements.details: One supplemental essay required (250 words) focusing on being a 'bridge builder' and connecting diverse perspectives, backgrounds, or ideas. While sometimes labeled 'optional,' it is strongly encouraged and considered very important.

supplemental_requirements.target_program: Artistic Programs (e.g., Tisch School of the Arts, some Steinhardt programs)
supplemental_requirements.details: Required for specific artistic programs. Applicants are encouraged to submit artistic materials approximately one month before the application deadline.

holistic_factors.specific_differentiators: Seeks 'bridge builders' who can connect people, groups, and ideas; intellectual curiosity, ambition, resilience, creativity; strong fit with a global, diverse, and vibrant urban environment.

major_selection_tactics: Apply to less competitive majors if not set on highly selective fields like CS or Business, especially at NYU where Stern has a significantly lower acceptance rate.
Consider undeclared for Colleges of Arts and Science, as major choice often doesn't impact admission for these schools, allowing for exploration during freshman year.

Research major-specific admit rates and perceived difficulty before applying; some programs like Psychology, Sociology, or certain majors in Gallatin, Liberal Studies, or the School of Professional Studies at NYU are often considered easier to get into.
Choose a major that is broad enough to provide several career options.
Examine the course catalog for degrees you are interested in and choose the one with the most classes you like and the fewest you dislike.
college_ranking_tactics: Rank colleges based on General Education (GE) requirements, considering their ease and potential overlap with your declared major.
Prioritize colleges with desirable housing quality and location, as these significantly impact quality of life.
Look into dining hall options and their operating hours when evaluating colleges.
Consider campus amenities like gyms, game rooms, and study areas.
Factor in transportation convenience, such as bus routes and parking availability.
application_strategy.alternate_major_strategy: If applying to a competitive major, list a backup in a different, less competitive college or school. For example, if applying to CS in Engineering, list Cognitive Science in Letters and Science as an alternate. At NYU, if applying to a highly competitive program like Stern, consider listing majors in Tandon (Business and Technology Management), School of Professional Studies (Sports Management, Real Estate, Hotel & Tourism Management), or Gallatin as alternate programs, as these may have higher acceptance rates.

scholarships.name: NYU Promise
scholarships.amount: Meets 100% of Demonstrated Financial Need (full tuition for families under $100k income with typical assets)
scholarships.deadline: Early Decision I: November 10, 2025; Early Decision II: January 10, 2026; Regular Decision: February 1, 2026 (for CSS Profile)
scholarships.benefits: Full demonstrated financial need met without loans

scholarships.name: Presidential Honors Scholars Program
scholarships.amount: Up to $32,000 annually, renewable for four years
scholarships.deadline: Automatic consideration with admission application (apply by priority deadline)
scholarships.benefits: Seminars, faculty mentoring, research grants, study away opportunities, leadership and service activities

scholarships.name: Martin Luther King, Jr. Scholars Program
scholarships.deadline: Express interest on Common Application and select on NYU Writing Supplement
scholarships.benefits: High-impact experiences including seminars, service-learning, funding for research/unpaid internships, global/domestic travel

scholarships.name: NYU Stern Scholars Program
scholarships.amount: Full-ride scholarship (tuition, fees, and sometimes room and board)
scholarships.benefits: Bespoke learning experiences, academic excellence, community building, career readiness
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration upon admission to Stern School of Business

scholarships.name: Meyers Nursing Scholars Program
scholarships.deadline: Automatic consideration upon admission to Rory Meyers College of Nursing
scholarships.benefits: Supports two incoming first-year students, preference for first-generation, high-achieving with financial need
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration upon admission to Rory Meyers College of Nursing

scholarships.name: Distinguished Scholars Award (NYU SPS Graduate)
scholarships.deadline: Apply by the first-round application deadline for guaranteed consideration
scholarships.benefits: Support for new graduate students in NYU School of Professional Studies
scholarships.application_method: Automatic consideration based on application for admission; no additional application or FAFSA required

scholarships.name: AnBryce Scholarship Program (NYU Law)
scholarships.deadline: Indicate interest on NYU Law application
scholarships.benefits: Mentoring, networking opportunities, career support for first-generation law students
scholarships.application_method: Indicate interest on NYU Law application

ap_policy.general_rule: Score of 4 or 5 grants credit for most exams
exceptions: Some departments may require specific scores or have different policies
No credit awarded for studio art or business examinations
Credit for Computer Science may not count toward the major
History major has a maximum of 4 AP credits
Latin and German majors may not have course requirements reduced by AP credit
Students cannot receive credit for both the AP examination and the equivalent NYU course
No credit awarded for Seminar and Research courses in the AP/Cambridge Capstone program
ap_policy.usage: Can satisfy general education requirements, some major prerequisites, and elective credits. Up to 8 points can be allocated to general education requirements, with additional credits as electives. Maximum advanced standing credits is 32.

ib_policy.general_rule: HL exams with 6+ grant credit, up to 8 credits per exam

transfer_articulation.restrictions: Transfer credit awarded for post-secondary courses taken within a 10-year period prior to matriculation; minimum grade of C or better required; courses must be applicable to the degree program requirements and correspond to NYU courses; maximum of 64 transfer credits for a bachelor's degree for most schools for external transfer students, with exceptions for Steinhardt (up to 72) and Division of Applied Undergraduate Studies (DAUS) (up to 80); first-year students can receive a maximum of 32 transfer credits; no advanced standing offered at NYU Abu Dhabi or NYU Shanghai; generally no transfer credit for non-traditional learning formats (with exceptions for the School of Professional Studies); no transfer credit for physical education courses; first-year students cannot transfer expository writing courses; cannot earn credit for the same subject matter through a combination of AP, IB, A Level, and/or other international exams

what_it_takes: Strong academic record, including high GPA and rigorous coursework
Demonstrated talent and ability, especially relevant for specific programs
Well-written, authentic essays that reflect self-awareness and fit with NYU
Strong standardized test scores (if submitted), considered "very important"
common_activities: Research experience, particularly with a global outlook or social impact
Leadership roles in school clubs and organizations (e.g., Model UN, Debate Society, GirlUp club)
Community service and fundraising campaigns, especially those addressing social issues
Involvement in arts and humanities, reflecting personal passions
Internships and practical experiences related to academic interests
essay_tips: Be specific and detailed about why NYU is the right fit for you and your chosen program
Show, don't tell, using anecdotes and examples to illustrate your qualities and experiences
Connect your experiences to NYU's dynamic, interconnected, and global academic community, emphasizing "bridge-builder" qualities
Be authentic and genuinely share something new about yourself; avoid generic statements
Proofread thoroughly by reading your writing out loud to catch errors
red_flags: Generic essays that could apply to any institution
Submitting extra, unrequested letters of recommendation beyond the specified limit
Waiting until the last minute to submit applications, especially for artistic programs with portfolios/auditions
Obsessing over message boards and forums for admissions predictions, as they are often incorrect
Using a current school email address that may become inaccessible after leaving
insights: NYU is highly selective, with acceptance rates around 9-12%
While some sources indicate demonstrated interest is not a significant factor, others state it is "considered" and can be valuable through engagement with the university
Applying Early Decision is one of the strongest ways to demonstrate interest
The university values diversity in its student body, with students from all 50 states and over 130 countries
Many students value the independence and extensive opportunities for internships, research, and cultural activities that come with NYU's urban and global presence
